mxCell.value: Module 2 - Budget Review

<<Budget>>

Here you can see the current month as well as previous and future months.
I clicked calendar #3!

<<Budget>>

Let's say you want to compare several months at once.

Depending on your browser zoom level, you can select up to six months at a time. Please click the third calendar icon.
highlight: calendar_icons

<<Budget>>

Now you can view three months. Let's change the view so you can see a different set of months using the purple selection.
highlight: months_band

<<Budget>>

Below the current month, there are several pieces of information and an amount labeled "To Budget."
highlight: budget_header

<<Budget>>

Please select the purple number to see some options for this amount. There are multiple ways to move money around your budget. After all, it's meant to be flexible!

<<Budget>>

Let's move on to the Budget Table! This is the table below the Budget Summary where you will budget dollars, update your categories, and adjust your budget table based on your assigned scenario.

<<Budget>>

The budget table is a digital cash envelope system. You create categories relevant to your life and budget dollars accordingly. 

As your digital teacher, I will walk through each of the categories, and MyBudgetCoach will automatically build most of your budget table throughout this Module.

<<Budget>>

First up is the Category column. The Category column houses the names of each category.

<<Budget>>

The first column that will have dollar amounts is the Budgeted column. The Budgeted column is where you'll be entering amounts to budget available dollars in advance of your spending.

This is how you create a plan for how you want to use your income prior to spending.

<<Budget>>

Next up is the Spent column. This shows you what you've actually spent in a category throughout the month. 

When you categorize a transaction in your Account, that amount is added to the total Spent for that category.

<<Budget>>

To the left of the header 'Category' at the top of the Budget Table, select the three dots. This gives you visual options. You can show and hide hidden categories and collapse or expand categories.

<<Budget>>

When you hover to the right of a Category name, an arrow appears. The rows that have bold text are called "Category Groups." 

The arrow in a Category Group row has options to add a category, hide that category group, rename that category group, or delete that category group.
Module 1 - Section 3

<<Accounts>>

Select the date section within the blank transaction row and choose today's date.

<<Accounts>>

For the category, select "Bills."

<<Accounts>>

Finish this transaction by selecting the check mark to turn it green.

<<Accounts>>

Notice the account balance is now $900, which is $1,000 - $100.
highlight: account_balance

<<Accounts>>

Let's delete these pretend transactions. Go ahead and hover on the left side of the date to un-hide a box. Select the box for each of the two transactions.

<<Accounts>>

Alright [[student_name]], that wraps up Module 1! Excellent work and you are off to a great start.

<<Accounts>>

To the right hand side of the search box, select the purple text with '2 transactions' to see a series of options.

Select 'Delete' to remove those transactions.
As your digital teacher, I have written this conversation you are reading now in advance. I am not AI nor a chat bot.
Tell me more!

Hello!

Welcome to the MyBudgetCoach. This is an interactive teaching guide on how to build and use a budget. In addition to your current teacher, I am your digital teacher who will support you in learning how to budget.

Please select the purple button below to start your lesson.

<<Accounts>>

There are just a few more functions to point out on the Account screen.

<<Accounts>>

The 'Import' button allows you to upload an export of transactions from your bank.
highlight: import_button

<<Accounts>>

The 'Filter' button allows you to filter down the transactions you are viewing by certain criteria (date, payee, category...).
highlight: filter_button

<<Accounts>>

The 'Undo' and 'Redo' buttons are helpful tools when you are working in this screen.

Please note: These are also available in the Budget screen as well. However, when selected, they will 'Undo' or 'Redo' your last action completed for either Accounts or Budget, depending on where your last action was.

<<Accounts>>

This is the 'Search' bar. As you type, whether text or numbers, the list of transactions will dynamically filter down based on criteria entered.
highlight: search_bar

<<Accounts>>

This is the 'Split/Toggle' button. If you happen to have split transactions, this button will expand or collapse those transactions from view.
highlight: split_toggle_button

<<Accounts>>

These three dots show additional options.

<<Accounts>>

1. Show running balance
2. Hide 'cleared' checkboxes
3. Export
4. Reconcile
5. Link account
6. Close account
highlight: more_button

<<Accounts>>

Type "Cell Phone Company" as your Payee and select "+ Create Cell Phone Company" to save the payee.
highlight: select_payee
highlight: select_category

<<Accounts>>

Now, enter $100 in the Payment column of the transaction row.
highlight: payment_input

<<Accounts>>

Now select "Add" to save the transaction and then select "Cancel" to get out of adding transactions.
highlight: cleared_status_icon
highlight: save_transaction
highlight: months_band
highlight: budget_table
highlight: category_column
highlight: budgeted_column
highlight: spent_column
highlight: balance_column

<<Budget>>

The rows below a Category Group row, without bold text, are called Categories.

When you hover over a Category row, the arrow that appears gives you the option to Hide, Rename, and Delete that Category.

<<Budget>>

Also when you hover on a Category row, a small paper icon appears. Selecting this opens up a note box. This can be used to capture helpful information about that category.

For example, the amount you intend to budget each month based on the scenario you are assigned.

<<Budget>>

When you hover over the month at the top of the budget summary, two up arrows are shown to the left. Selecting this will collapse the budget summary view to only show the 'To Budget' amount.

You can expand by hovering over the month and then selecting the two arrows (now pointing down) to the left of the month.

<<Budget>>

To the right of the name of the month there are three vertical dots. Selecting this shows additional options that can have dollars budgeted to all your categories in one click.

<<Budget>>

These options include:

1. Copy last month's budget
2. Set budgets to zero
3. Set budgets to 3 month average
highlight: budget_more_button
highlight: selected_transactions_button
Let's Begin!
Before I introduce myself, I would like to learn more about you! Please enter your first name.

Next
student_name = [student_input]

Nice to meet you, [[student_name]]! 

My name is Mr. Phelan, but you can refer to me as Rob. I am a teacher from Maryland. I created this curriculum to help teach students, like yourself, learn how to create and use a budget.
Nice to meet you, Rob!

Instead of just using paper and pencil, your teacher has decided to integrate the use of this software program called MyBudgetCoach. This will help give you the tools to be successful far after the completion of these modules. 

Adults use MyBudgetCoach every day to budget, and now you will too!
Yeah! No more pen and paper...
Although you will work through these instructions, and future modules on your own, your teacher will see your progress in the Message Center.

You are now working through the Introduction module. The following is a review of what you will complete.

1. Module 1 - Account Set-Up
2. Module 2 - Budget Review
3. Module 3 - Budget Set-Up
4. Module 4 - Budgeted Amounts for Each Category
Before we start off with Module 1 - Account Set-Up, let me walk you through how to use this digital conversation with me, Rob, as your digital teacher.
If you have any questions along the way, you can ask your teacher for help.
I will ask my teacher if I have a question

If you want to review a step again, select the 'Back' button below. If you want to hide the avatar conversation, select the 'x' at the top left of my picture. You can continue the conversation by selecting the 'Introduction' conversation in the left side menu.

In the bottom right window of an open conversation, there are three vertical dots. This gives you the option to:

1) Give Feedback
2) Reset This Conversation
3) End This Conversation

[[student_name]], there may be times in the modules that I ask you to enter something into a blank box, just like I did earlier when I asked you what your first name was. Please read the instructions carefully and complete the steps as instructed. This will ensure you know how to complete future actions in later modules.
Start Module 1
Alright, [[student_name]]! Let's begin with Module 1 - Account set-up.

Module 1 - 
Sections 1 & 2

<<Accounts>>

Module 1 - Account set-up, has three sections:

1. Updating Budget File Name
2. Adding an Account
3. Adding a Transaction

<<Accounts>>

You can have multiple budget files in your MyBudgetCoach account. Each budget file can be its own scenario. Your teacher will instruct you when to create a new budget file. For now, you will just be working within just one budget file.

<<Accounts>>

To help your teacher know this is your budget file, and not your classmate's, please name the budget file with: FirstName LastNameInitial_MonthYear. For example, "Rob P_Dec2024."
I updated the name of my budget file

<<Accounts>>

To rename your budget file, select your Budget Name in the top left and select 'Rename budget' to update. 

As a reminder, name the budget file "Rob P_Dec2024" updating for your name and the current month and year, and click Enter.
highlight: budget_name
Let's start Section 2 of Module 1

<<Accounts>>

That completes Section 1 of Module 1!

Let's now move to Section 2 of Module 1 - Adding Account.

<<Accounts>>

MyBudgetCoach allows users to add a "Local" account, which is what you will do shortly. 

Local refers to an unlinked account. A linked account is an account that pulls in transactions from your bank. 

If you decide to use MyBudgetCoach once you have your own bank account, you can decide to link your account.

<<Accounts>>

In this scenario, we will add just a checking account. 

A checking account is a bank account people use to have the majority of their bills be paid out of and their income to be paid into so they can pay their bills. 

Generally, someone will just have one checking account. People may also have a credit card, but all transactions for this scenario will be in the checking account.

<<Accounts>>

Please select "+ Add Account" in the left menu bar.
highlight: add_account

<<Accounts>>

Great work [[student_name]]! You have now completed Section 2 of Module 1. 

Let's move to Section 3 - Adding Transactions, the last section within Module 1.

<<Accounts>>

Now that you have updated your budget file name and added your checking account, let's talk through how to add a transaction.

<<Accounts>>

As a friendly reminder, don't forget to select the "Back" button if you want to review a step again.

<<Accounts>>

For any bank account or credit card, there are two types of transactions: those that increase the balance, and those that decrease the balance. 

For a checking account, when you get paid by your job, the amount of income will be entered in the "Deposit" column.

<<Accounts>>

Transactions that decrease the balance when you spend money, such as paying rent or buying groceries, will have an amount in the "Payment" column.

<<Accounts>>

Let's review! 

Transactions that INCREASE the balance of your checking account will have an amount in the "Deposit" column and transactions that DECREASE the balance of your checking account will have an amount in the "Payment" column.

<<Accounts>>

Let's now add some hypothetical transactions.

We will start off with adding a paycheck and then later on, pay your cell phone bill.

<<Accounts>>

Select "+ Add New" in the top menu bar and select today's date.
highlight: add_new_button

<<Accounts>>

For the category, select "Income."

<<Accounts>>

Type "Job" as your Payee and select "+ Create Payee Job" to save the payee.
highlight: select_payee
highlight: select_category

<<Accounts>>

Finish this transaction by selecting the check mark to turn it green. This action "clears" the transaction.

<<Accounts>>

Notice the account balance went from $0 to $1,000 because you added income from your job as a Deposit.
highlight: account_balance

<<Accounts>>

Now, enter $1,000 in the Deposit column of the transaction row.
highlight: payment_input

<<Accounts>>

Now select "Add". 

Please note, you can select "Cancel" to get out of adding transactions after we pay the cell phone bill.
highlight: cleared_status_icon
highlight: save_transaction

<<Accounts>>

Let's now add a transaction for paying the cell phone bill.

<<Accounts>>

Great work adding those transactions, [[student_name]]!

<<Accounts>>

Please now send a message to your teacher in the Message Center, "I have completed Module 1 and am ready to begin Module 2" and await further instructions for when you should continue on to Module 2.

Welcome back [[student_name]]! Let's kick off Module 2 - Budget Review. This module includes the following two sections:

1. Budget Summary Review
2. Budget Table Review
Please navigate from Accounts to the Budget. Please select the Budget section within the left side menu bar.

<<Budget>>

The Budget screen includes two main sections: the Budget Summary and the Budget Table.

Let's start off with the months listed above the Budget Summary section.

<<Budget>>

Before we start building out the budget categories, let me teach you some additional navigation and editing options for the Budget Table.

<<Budget>>

Great work [[student_name]]! You have now completed the review of the software. You have learned about the Accounts throughout Module 1, and just completed the Budget overview within Module 2.
Module 3 - Budget set-up

<<Budget>>

Please now send a message to your teacher in the Message Center, "I have completed Module 2 and am ready to begin Module 3" and await further instructions for when you should continue on to Module 3.
Welcome back [[student_name]]! Let's kick off Module 3 - Budget set-up.

<<Budget>>

Within this Module, the software will help build your budget table by automatically adding the categories that will be needed to budget for your lifestyle.

I will provide a summary of each category after the software has added it to your budget table.

<<Budget>>

Before we begin, I want to point out that there is no "one-size-fits-all" when it comes to finances. Personal finance is personal and each person's budget will reflect their own individual needs, wants, and life situations.

<<Budget>>

The categories that we will review, and will be added to your Budget table, are to be viewed as a starting point for trying to determine a balanced way of spending money that allows:

1. Needs to be met
2. Wants to be included
3. Saving/investing (or debt paydown) to be prioritized
Language with a small blue triangle closely aligns to "Suggested Monthly Baseline Budget Percentages Website PDF.pdf" file provided by Rob

<<Budget>>

After each category name, there will be a percentage range. This will help you calculate the budgeted amount range based on your scenario selected.

For Example: A category name of "Housing (25-30%)" is recommending your Housing expenses should be in a range of 25-30% of your take home income (after taxes and deductions).

<<Budget>>

Ready to start building your budget table?

Select the button below to clear out the template budget categories, and add your first category.

<<Budget>>

Is that an emoji you see in the category name!? Yup!

The software allows you to customize the budget category names and include emojis. We have started off with a category for Housing.

delete_category_group: Usual Expenses
delete_category_group: Investments and Savings
create_category_group: Expenses
create_category: Expenses: Housing (25-30%)

<<Budget>>

After the software adds a category, I will give you an overview of the category and provide a list of which expenses should be categorized to that category.

Let's start off with Housing.

<<Budget>>

Housing is a very challenging category in many budgets across the U.S.. House prices, rent, and inflation have been rising and historically high compared to household incomes, which makes it extremely challenging to keep housing costs within the suggested parameters, particularly for
low-income individuals.

<<Budget>>

Things that should be included in your housing costs include:

- Mortgage payment or rent
- Property tax (usually included in a mortgage payment)
- Homeowners insurance (usually included in a mortgage payment)
- Furnishings
- House maintenance, cleaning, and repair
- Home upgrades
- Landscaping
- Home Owners Association (HOA) fees

<<Budget>>

The next category that was just added is Medical.
create_category: Expenses: Medical (2.5-10%)

<<Budget>>

This is such a challenging category for some households and barely a concern for others. Our age, genetics, lifestyle, and luck play a big role in how much gets allocated to medical expenses. Use FSA, HSA, or designated savings accounts to manage your health expenses if it makes sense for you.

<<Budget>>

Included in the medical expense category are:

- Copays for doctor visits
- Prescription costs
- Medical equipment needed
- In-home care or long term care
- Additional treatments or programs for preventative care
- Glasses and contacts
- Surgeries or hospital stays

<<Budget>>

If you have a chronic health condition, financially support a loved ones care, rely on a medication or treatment, or seem particularly accident-prone, you are going to need to have an increased allocation for this budget category, knowing that some months you may not use it and others may need a lot of use.

<<Budget>>

The next category that was just added is for Pets.
create_category: Expenses: Pets (0-5%)

<<Budget>>

Taking on the care and support of another living thing is not a decision to make lightly. You need to consider the total cost of pet ownership, and not just the initial purchase price, to determine if it is something that you can fit into your budget without exceeding the recommended budget allowance or taking money away from another core need.

<<Budget>>

Included in the pets category are:

- Purchase price or adoption fees
- Vaccinations
- Spay or Neuter
- Food (what if they have special dietary needs?)
- Litter
- Toys and accessories
- Regular check-ups and vet visits
- Grooming
- Pet sitter or boarding cost during travel
- Unexpected medical expenses or home damage

<<Budget>>

The next category that was just added is for Saving and Investing.
create_category: Expenses: Save/Invest (10-20%)

<<Budget>>

Saving and investing can include short, medium, and long term goals, whilst also providing additional security for you from financial disasters.

<<Budget>>

Your saving and investing section of your budget should include:

- Adding to your emergency fund (aiming for 3-6 months of expenses)
- Short term goals such as an upcoming purchase within the next 6 months
- Medium term goals such as a purchase within the next 6 month to 5 years.
- Long term goals for use more than 5 years from now.
- Sinking funds for annual expenses such as insurance premiums or HOA dues.

<<Budget>>

I would also include debt paydown in this slice of the budget (as well as others such as a car payment in transportation costs or a mortgage payment in housing) since that is also a big part of building your net worth.
Awkward wording - Follow up with Rob as his language.

<<Budget>>

Your saving and investing section of your budget should include (continued):

- Replacement and repair fund for your house or car
- Travel fund for vacations
- Wedding fund (for you or for attending weddings in the future)
- Gift fund (Christmas, birthdays, anniversaries, and Valentines Day all come at the same point each year. Save a little each month so it doesnt break your budget when the time comes).
- Taxes if you make additional income and need to put aside taxes for when you file.

<<Budget>>

Money should be invested for goals that are generally more than 5 years away using accounts such as retirement accounts, brokerage accounts, education savings accounts, or health savings accounts.

If you think you will need the money within the next 5 years, move the money to a savings account or switch to a low risk investment such as a Treasury Bond.
There is a lot here. Rob's words, but should we pair down.

<<Budget>>

The next category that was just added is for Gifts and Giving.
create_category: Expenses: Gifts/Giving (5-10%)

<<Budget>>

Gifts are something that most of us can agree on. We live in a culture that has rituals around gift giving at different events in our lives and on the calendar.

Many of us feel a desire (or pressure) to participate in these customs, but that can be very expensive at times and force us into very challenging budget situations if we are not prepared ahead of time.

<<Budget>>

Things to think about in your Gifts and Giving category include:

- Donations to charity
- Tithing
- Being generous to those in need with money, gift cards, food, clothing, etc.
- Major holidays such as Christmas, Hannukah, Kwanzaa, Diwali, Valentines Day, Easter, Fathers and Mothers Day, Halloween, etc.
- Personal life events such as birthdays, anniversaries, weddings, baby showers, graduations, house warming, retirement, bridal showers, bachelor or bachelorette parties, etc.
- General life gifting such as for a romantic gesture or to support a friend

<<Budget>>

The Gifts and Giving category can be shared with the Investing and Saving category added earlier, but I know that I also will typically have some sort of event each month that requires a gift (especially as my son has started school and is getting regular birthday invitations), so I tend to include a section in my budget for accommodating that.

<<Budget>>

Switching gears now from Gifting to Giving. Giving is a very personal budget category and will be different for every person. We can choose to give in ways that do not involve money such as with our time, skills, or expertise, but many people want to be able to give part of their money to those less fortunate than us or to support causes that we strongly believe in.

<<Budget>>

Since the Gifts and Giving category can change each month, use something like a dedicated savings account to house the money for this fund, a budgeting app or spreadsheet, or even a cash envelope for tracking how much you have left.

<<Budget>>

The next category that was just added is for Food.
create_category: Expenses: Food (10-15%)

<<Budget>>

Food is another one of the big three (with housing and transportation) as a place where we tend to spend a larger percentage of our net pay. Its also a category that gets very impacted by inflation and the cost of living in an area. Food can also be disproportionally more expensive for lower income earners than high income earners. Since theres a limit to how much we can/need to eat, we dont need to keep allocating more money to it as our income grows.

<<Budget>>

Things to consider in your food category:

- Groceries
- Take out and restaurants
- Food delivery or grocery shopper app fees
- Meal prep services
- Snacks
- Meal plans in college or work
- Supplements
- Food gifts and parties

<<Budget>>

Entertainment can also have a crossover with food since many forms of entertainment involve food as well. Think of eating out with friends, going on a date, or hosting a party.

Just make sure those costs are being included in your budget somewhere and not falling in between the cracks.

<<Budget>>

The next category that was just added is for Utilities.
create_category: Expenses: Utilities (5-10%)

<<Budget>>

Utilities is another category that is disproportionally more expensive for lower income households. We dont typically have to pay more for heating, electricity, or gas as our incomes rise (unless we inflate our lives with bigger houses) so we can expect this category to take up a lower percentage of our budgets as we increase our take-home pay.

<<Budget>>

Things to include in your utilities category:

- Water
- Gas
- Electricity
- Sewer
- Oil
- Internet
- Cell phone plan
- Home security

<<Budget>>

While services such as cell phones and internet can be included in this budget slice, its important to differentiate between what is a need (included in this slice) and what is a want or luxury (to be included in other slices, such as entertainment or subscriptions).

<<Budget>>

The next category that was just added is for Transportation.
create_category: Expenses: Transport. (5-15%)

<<Budget>>

The last of the big three (with housing and food) where we tend to spend a larger section of our budget pie. There are many modes of transportation and many levels of luxury and utility within those. Like housing and food, this is an easy category to overspend in and one of the most important to make conscious spending decisions in before being locked into a situation for several years.

<<Budget>>

Things to include in your transportation category:

- Purchase price and/or car payment
- Monthly expected gas cost
- Car insurance (can be included here or in the insurance category which will be added in the future)
- Maintenance and repair
- Parking fees
- Tolls
- Tags and title

<<Budget>>

The next category that was just added is for Clothing.
create_category: Expenses: Clothing (1-5%)

<<Budget>>

Most months I can get away with a 0% clothing budget, but I do acknowledge that not everyone is like me where clothing is a low priority item, and I can afford to shop for clothes once or twice a year when extra income comes in from side hustles.

Clothing, like food, has tiers based on our needs and wants. What we need to survive is quite basic, so once those needs are met each new piece of clothing has to be evaluated for the utility and desire it fulfills.

<<Budget>>

Things to consider for your clothing category include:

- Clothing that requires replacing due to wear and tear such as everyday footwear
- Work attire
- Sports and workout equipment and clothing/accessories
- Seasonal clothing needs
- Clothing for travel
- Formal wear for events such as weddings

<<Budget>>

If clothing and style is important to you, then this slice of your budget may be larger at the expense of other areas such as a larger house, fancier car, or high-quality food.

There are lots of fun ways to save on clothing and be frugal without being cheap, and there are ways to spend more now with the idea of getting higher quality items that will last longer and lower your clothing budget needs down the road.

<<Budget>>

If you are like me and you only buy clothes a couple of times per year, consider setting up a sinking fund in a savings account where you put aside money for the months when you binge buying clothes.

<<Budget>>

The next category that was just added is for Personal Care (2.5-5%).
create_category: Expenses: Pers. Care (2.5-5%)

<<Budget>>

Like most categories, this slice of our budget has definite needs and then a spectrum of wants. Figuring out which are which is not a simple job and is often up for debate. This category is dedicated towards your personal health and wellness. It includes core products and services as well as more luxury items that can have very positive impacts on aspects of our health.

<<Budget>>

Things to include in personal care are:

- Oral care equipment and products
- Hair care products and services
- Skin care products and services
- Makeup
- Shower products
- Massages
- Feminine hygiene products

<<Budget>>

The next category that was just added is for Insurance.
create_category: Expenses: Insurance (5-10%)

<<Budget>>

Depending on your age, employment situation, family size, and health status, this could be a small section of your budget or a large one. Many employers include health and dental insurance benefits as well as some others such as life insurance or disability insurance, whilst self-employed individuals typically have to sort all of this out for themselves.

<<Budget>>

Insurance you need and should consider for this category of your budget:

- Health
- Dental
- Life
- Auto
- Short-term disability
- Long-term disability
- Homeowners
- Renters
- Long term care
- Umbrella
- Travel
- Jewelry

<<Budget>>

Some categories may already be absorbing parts of your insurance costs such as homeowners or renters insurance, and auto insurance, but there are others that you will want to include in this section of your budget.

<<Budget>>

Subscriptions that should be considered include:

- Phone apps
- TV streaming services
- Gaming
- Music
- Hobbies
- Kids entertainment
- Meal prep
- Amazon Prime

<<Budget>>

Subscriptions that should be considered include (continued):

- Gym membership
- Fitness or sports classes
- Cloud storage
- Storage units
- Magazines or newspapers
- Credit card memberships

<<Budget>>

The next category that was just added is for Subscriptions.
create_category: Expenses: Subscriptions (0-5%)

<<Budget>>

Subscriptions are services for which you pay a regular fee to use as opposed to a single purchase. While there are some subscriptions that can be considered a need or close to it (I pay for a MailChimp subscription to manage my website and email newsletter, or Canva for graphic design), most will probably fall into the category of I could live without it."

<<Budget>>

Things to consider for Entertainment include:

- Events with friends
- Concerts
- Movie theatres
- Hobbies
- Sports
- Gambling
- Family events

<<Budget>>

Things to consider for Entertainment include (continued):

- Gaming purchases
- Phone app purchases
- Toys
- Entry fees for parks, museums, monuments
- Dining out (if not in food budget)
- Games and puzzles
- Plants

<<Budget>>

The next category that was just added is for Entertainment and Travel.
create_category: Expenses: Ent. / Travel (2.5-10%)

<<Budget>>

Entertainment is such a broad category and often it will overlap with others (Food, Subscriptions, Transportation), but this is the category for all things fun and leisure that doesnt get put into the others. Traveling is not something that every person wants to do, but if you do, its going to require some conscious budgeting to fit it in. You may be including it in your Saving and Investing slice already, but if not its got to come from here.

<<Budget>>

Things to include in this category for Travel include:

- Travel
- Accommodation
- Food
- Entertainment on the trip

<<Budget>>

That was the final category! You now have a starting budget table. A few more things before we wrap-up Module 3.

<<Budget>>

Budgeting is extremely personal and all of the suggested percentages are just starting points for assessing your own spending and planning for the future to meet your goals. You may need more in some categories and less in others, and that is totally fine.

<<Budget>>

Now that you have built a budget table, it is time to calculate what budgeted amounts should be used for each category.
Module 4 - Budgeted Amounts for Each Category

<<Budget>>

For some religions, there is a culture of giving a percentage of your income to your religious organization to fund their work in the community and abroad.

<<Budget>>

Many of us shop at a grocery store which also carries items such as household products, gifts, clothing, and more. Make sure you are separating out those costs or allocating money from those budget categories to your Food Budget if you are going to be subtracting your entire grocery store receipt for this area.

<<Budget>>

This is a factor to consider and you may be able to shrink your medical budget a little to increase your allocation for food if you are attempting to prevent medical issues in the future through the food you eat. Having a meal plan and thinking intentionally about the food you want to eat each week can help to reduce costs and waste.

<<Budget>>

You could also choose to lump some of this category into housing which would allow you to raise the percentage of your income going towards housing, but I like to keep it separate to see how our money is being spent and where there is room to make improvements or cut spending.

<<Budget>>

Things to include in your transportation category (continued):

- Inspection fees
- Emissions test
- Replacement tires or seasonal tires
- Ride-share or taxi costs
- Public transit passes or ticket costs

<<Budget>>

Consider your transportation options and where you need to go before making the decision to buy a car. If you do need to buy a car, be sure to consider your needs, wants, and budget before beginning the search for a vehicle.

The total cost of car ownership is another important factor to consider since that will have a lasting impact on your budget, long after you have purchased the vehicle.

<<Budget>>

There can be an overlap here with your medical budget depending on the service (dental visits come to mind), so make sure you are allocating items to one section or combining them together within your budget.

<<Budget>>

One of the easiest ways to make wins in your budget is to check on all the subscriptions you are currently signed up for and see if there are any that you are not using or could stop paying for until you actually need it.

<<Budget>>

The key is to maintain the essential equation of income needs to be greater than or equal to all expenses and saving. Increased spending in one area must come at the expense of another to avoid the need to rely on debt.

Entered!
credit_card_balance = [user_input]
Please pick a credit card account, and enter your current credit card balance as a positive number. The current balance can be found on the left hand side next to the account name.

Entered!
balance_credit_card_category = [user_input]

<<Budget>>

For that same credit card, navigate to the category row, and please enter the current amount shown in the Balance column as a positive number.
Show me the results!
Thanks for entering those numbers!
calculate_new_variable: credit_card_payment = credit_card_balance - balance_credit_card_category
The software has completed the calculation of the credit card payment for you.

<<Budget>>

Credit Card Payment =  [[credit_card_payment]]

This was calculated by taking your Current credit card balance ([[credit_card_balance]]) - Balance amount of credit card category ([[balance_credit_card_category]]).

<<Budget>>

Each of the budget category names include the percentage range for what the budgeted amount should be for each category.

<<Budget>>

At this point, you should have been assigned a job position and have been given an amount of income you receive each month.

<<Budget>>

Great work [[student_name]]! You have now completed creating your budget table. Please now send a message to your teacher in the Message Center, "I have completed Module 3 and am ready to begin Module 4" and await further instructions for when you should continue on to Module 4.

Entered!
income = [user_input]

<<Budget>>

This Module will walk through how to calculate the budgeted amount range for each category. We will complete one example together with an assumed income of $5,000 per month. Please enter $5,000 in the box below.

Entered!
lower_percentage = [user_input]

<<Budget>>

Please enter one of the category percentages as a decimal. Let's use Housing. The percentage range for Housing is 25-30%. Please enter "0.25" as the lower percentage in the box below.

Entered!
higher_percentage = [user_input]

<<Budget>>

Please now enter "0.30" as the higher percentage in the box below.
calculate_new_variable: lower_amount = income - 3750

<<Budget>>

The software will now use those inputs to calculate the lower and higher budgeted amounts to give you a range for how much you can spend on housing, assuming a salary of $5,000 per month.

<<Budget>>

Show me the results!
calculate_new_variable: higher_amount = income - 3500

<<Budget>>

The range of your budget for housing using an assumed income of $5,000 per month is:

$[[lower_amount]] to $[[higher_amount]]

<<Budget>>

Please enter this range into the "Notes" for the Housing category. To access the Notes, hover over the category name to reveal a paper icon. Select the paper icon and enter the $[[lower_amount]] to $[[higher_amount]].

<<Budget>>

Once the note is added, if you hover over the paper icon to the right of the category name, the note entered will appear. This will be a good reference guide so you don't need to calculate the budgeted amount each time you want to budget dollars for a category.

<<Budget>>

Please use a calculator to calculate the lower and higher amounts for each of your budget categories and enter the range in a note for each category.
I have completed Module 4!

<<Budget>>

Once you have calculated all the budgeted ranges and entered them as Notes, please send a message to your teacher letting them know you have completed Module 4. Great work!
highlight: more_button
highlight: budget_header
highlight: budget_table

<<Accounts>>

Now follow these steps:

1. Select "Create local account"

2. Name your account "First Name_Checking Account"

3. Select a type of "For Budget: Checking" 

4. Enter a starting balance of $0

<<Budget>>

Each envelope is labeled with a purpose. Rent, Food, Utilities, etc. You stuff those envelopes with the money from pay day.

<<Budget>>

When your available dollars in the 'To Budget' has gone to $0, that means no more money is available to go into envelopes. You either have to wait until the payday, move money from on category to another, or commit to not spend money in that unfunded category.

<<Budget>>

You are only going to budget the dollars you have available in your account. As part of the scenario, you will be adding transactions in phases, so you will need to plan for expenses to ensure they can be paid on one paycheck, prior to the next one arriving.
Welcome back [[student_name]]! Let's kick off Module 4 - Budgeted Amounts for Each Category.

<<Budget>>

The last column is Balance. This shows you what you have available to spend. If it's negative and red, you've overspent the category.

If the amount is positive and black, the amount shown is what you have remaining to spend throughout the rest of the month.

<<Budget>>

If you don't cover this overspending, you risk over-spending you checking account balance. This is also known as an "overdraft of your account" and banks generally charge a fee when this occurs.

You always want to avoid spending more than you have available. Having a plan for how you will use your income in advance can reduce that risk.
